column2: We next inquire about the angels in comparison with corporeal things; and in the first place about their comparison with bodies; secondly, of the angels in comparison with corporeal places; and, thirdly, of their comparison with local movement.
column3: We next inquire about the angels in comparison with corporeal things; and in the first place about their comparison with bodies; secondly, of the angels in comparison with corporeal places; and, thirdly, of their comparison with local movement.

column2: Objection 1: It would seem that angels have bodies naturally united to them.
column3: Objection one: It would seem that angels have bodies naturally united to them.

column2: Therefore angels have bodies naturally united to them.
column3: Therefore angels have bodies naturally united to them.

column2: For whatever belongs to any nature as an accident is not found universally in that nature; thus, for instance, to have wings, because it is not of the essence of an animal, does not belong to every animal.
column3: For whatever belongs to any nature as an accident is not found universally in that nature; thus, for instance, to have wings, because it is not of the essence of an animal, does not belong to every animal.

column2: Consequently not all intellectual substances are united to bodies; but some are quite separated from bodies, and these we call angels.
column3: Consequently not all intellectual substances are united to bodies; but some are quite separated from bodies, and these we call angels.

column2: Whether Angels Assume Bodies?
column3: Whether Angels Assume Bodies?

column2: Objection 1: It would seem that angels do not assume bodies.
column3: Objection one: It would seem that angels do not assume bodies.

column2: For there is nothing superfluous in the work of an angel, as there is nothing of the kind in the work of nature.
column3: For there is nothing superfluous in the work of an angel, as there is nothing of the kind in the work of nature.

column2: Therefore an angel does not assume a body.
column3: Therefore an angel does not assume a body.

column2: Yet Divine Scripture from time to time introduces angels so apparent as to be seen commonly by all; just as the angels who appeared to Abraham were seen by him and by his whole family, by Lot, and by the citizens of Sodom; in like manner the angel who appeared to Tobias was seen by all present.
column3: Yet Divine Scripture from time to time introduces angels so apparent as to be seen commonly by all; just as the angels who appeared to Abraham were seen by him and by his whole family, by Lot, and by the citizens of Sodom; in like manner the angel who appeared to Tobias was seen by all present.

column2: Now by such a vision only a body can be beheld.
column3: Now by such a vision only a body can be beheld.

column2: Moreover that angels assumed bodies under the Old Law was a figurative indication that the Word of God would take a human body; because all the apparitions in the Old Testament were ordained to that one whereby the Son of God appeared in the flesh.
column3: Moreover that angels assumed bodies under the Old Law was a figurative indication that the Word of God would take a human body; because all the apparitions in the Old Testament were ordained to that one whereby the Son of God appeared in the flesh.

column2: Objection 1: It would seem that the angels exercise functions of life in assumed bodies.
column3: Objection one: It would seem that the angels exercise functions of life in assumed bodies.

column2: For pretence is unbecoming in angels of truth.
column3: For pretence is unbecoming in angels of truth.

column2: Consequently, the angel perceives by the assumed body; and this is the most special function of life.
column3: Consequently, the angel perceives by the assumed body; and this is the most special function of life.

column2: But it is evident from many passages of Sacred Scripture that angels spoke in assumed bodies.
column3: But it is evident from many passages of Sacred Scripture that angels spoke in assumed bodies.

column2: Therefore in their assumed bodies they exercise functions of life.
column3: Therefore in their assumed bodies they exercise functions of life.

column2: Therefore they cannot exercise functions of life through assumed bodies.
column3: Therefore they cannot exercise functions of life through assumed bodies.

column2: For the bodies are assumed merely for this purpose, that the spiritual properties and works of the angels may be manifested by the properties of man and of his works.
column3: For the bodies are assumed merely for this purpose, that the spiritual properties and works of the angels may be manifested by the properties of man and of his works.

column2: This could not so fittingly be done if they were to assume true men; because the properties of such men would lead us to men, and not to angels.
column3: This could not so fittingly be done if they were to assume true men; because the properties of such men would lead us to men, and not to angels.

column2: Consequently it can in no way be said that the angels perceive through the organs of their assumed bodies.
column3: Consequently it can in no way be said that the angels perceive through the organs of their assumed bodies.

column2: Yet the angels are moved accidentally, when such bodies are moved, since they are in them as movers are in the moved; and they are here in such a way as not to be elsewhere, which cannot be said of God.
column3: Yet the angels are moved accidentally, when such bodies are moved, since they are in them as movers are in the moved; and they are here in such a way as not to be elsewhere, which cannot be said of God.

column2: Accordingly, although God is not moved when the things are moved in which He exists, since He is everywhere; yet the angels are moved accidentally according to the movement of the bodies assumed.
column3: Accordingly, although God is not moved when the things are moved in which He exists, since He is everywhere; yet the angels are moved accidentally according to the movement of the bodies assumed.

column2: But the food taken by angels was neither changed into the assumed body, nor was the body of such a nature that food could be changed into it; consequently, it was not a true eating, but figurative of spiritual eating.
column3: But the food taken by angels was neither changed into the assumed body, nor was the body of such a nature that food could be changed into it; consequently, it was not a true eating, but figurative of spiritual eating.

column2: Hence by the sons of God are to be understood the sons of Seth, who were good; while by the daughters of men the Scripture designates those who sprang from the race of Cain.
